checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
The Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB) is a resource of tens of thousands of annotated gene sets for use with GSEA software, divided into Human and Mouse collections.


(From additional information) : The project plans to use the databases containing the names and relationships for human and mice data integrated with the databases.


Aligns with the approved research topic Biological research.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation classified in Prohibited Use Screening in accordance with LC 2.7.

checks.name: D5+M affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
Originating Organization: UC San Diego and BROAD institute(United States)
Not from a D5 country.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts
checks.notes: No finetuning scripts provided.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: No risk in LC2.7 check, inspection skipped.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes:
Source: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/msigdb

The following collections have been identified as for the downloads in additional information:

C5 (Ontology): This is needed for both the Biological Process (BP) and Molecular Function (MF) sub-collections to connect genes to the functional nodes in our GO.obo hierarchy.

C2:CP (Canonical Pathways): This interfaces with the Reactome and KEGG subsets. These provide the biochemical logic that simple GO terms often lack.

H (Hallmark): These will be super-nodes in our graph. They act as high-level cluster labels for our embeddings.

C3 (Regulatory Targets): This will help embeddings to capture why genes are co-expressed, C3 provides the link to shared Transcription Factors (TFs).

M5, M2, MH, M3: This will be required to follow similar logic for rodent research models.


Provenance: 
Owner / Curator: UC San Diego and BROAD institute

Primary Distribution Platform: MSigDB

Access Method: download via https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/downloads.jsp#msigdb

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
License: BSD-style

Use GSEA software and MSigDB gene sets for academic and non-profit research

Cite MSigDB and the Broad Institute in publications and presentations

Share results and figures, not the gene set files themselves

Don't Use MSigDB or GSEA for commercial purposes without explicit permission

Don't redistribute or mirror MSigDB gene set files (e.g., .gmt) publicly

Don't undle MSigDB gene sets into software, databases, or services for redistribution

Don't remove or alter license notices or attribution

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
The HGNC database contains over 43,000 approved human gene symbols and names, including approximately 19,200 protein-coding genes, 14,000 pseudogenes, and nearly 9,000 non-coding RNA genes PubMed, along with unique HGNC IDs, locus types, chromosomal locations, aliases, previous nomenclature, and links to external genomic, proteomic, and phenotypic databases.

The HGNC dataset is listed in additional information. It will support the proposal's Pillar One (Scaling Up the POC) for named entity recognition (NER) and knowledge graph enrichment, and Pillar Two (Train Life Science & Health Models) for harmonizing biomedical data sources and building training datasets for tokenization and NER models in the life sciences domain.

Aligns with the approved Research topic of Bioscience.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation classified in Prohibited Use Screening in accordance with LC 2.7.

checks.name: D5+M affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
The HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC) is a non-profit body funded by the US National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), operating under the auspices of HUGO (Human Genome Organisation).

The entity is from non-D5 country.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes:
Source: https://www.genenames.org/download/archive/#!/#tocAnchor-1-2


Dr. Phyllis McAlpine was largely responsible for setting up the human gene nomenclature committee, devising its Guidelines and promoting the use of standardised gene nomenclature, chairing it from 1988 until 1996; Professor Sue Povey chaired it from 1996-2007 at University College London, and Dr. Elspeth Bruford became project lead in 2007, relocating it to EMBL-EBI and later to the University of Cambridge in 2018.

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
License type: Creative Commons Public Domain (CC0) 
Permissions:

- Any form of reuse of the content is permitted.

- No restrictions are imposed on access to, or use of, the data provided by the HGNC.

- It is a condition of NIH funding that the nomenclature and information provided is freely available to all.

- Attribution is recommended but not mandatory (cite "HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee at the University of Cambridge" and the website URL). 

- Resource Identification Portal citation available: HGNC (RRID:SCR_002827).

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
MGI provides comprehensive phenotypes for over 50,000 mutant alleles in mice and provides experimental model descriptions for over 1,500 human diseases, including integrated genetic, genomic, and biological data on mouse genes, gene characterization, nomenclature, mapping, gene homologies among vertebrates, sequence links, phenotypes, allelic variants, mutants, strain data, and gene expression information.

The Mus musculus (MGI) dataset supports Pillar One by enabling cross-species data harmonization and enriching the knowledge graph with mouse-human orthology relationships. For Pillar Two, it provides experimentally validated gene-phenotype associations from over 50,000 mutant alleles to train and improve life science AI models. In Pillar Three, it facilitates target discovery and ranking through curated mouse models of over 1,500 human diseases with established pathway annotations.

Aligns with the approved Research topic of Bioscience.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation classified in Prohibited Use Screening in accordance with LC 2.7.

checks.name: D5+M affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
MGI is a free, online database and bioinformatics resource hosted by The Jackson Laboratory, with funding by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), the National Cancer Institute (NCI), and the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD).

All maintainer entities are from non-D5 country.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts
checks.notes: No user files provided.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: No risk identified in LC 2.7 check. Skipping inspection.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes:
Source: https://www.informatics.jax.org/ 

The first incarnation of what would become MGI was initiated in 1989, as a program project grant from the then National Center for Human Genome Research to JH Nadeau, LE Mobraaten, and JT Eppig entitled "Multilevel Analysis and Display of Mouse Genome Data." PubMed Central In 1992, that group joined with the team responsible for developing the "Genomic Database for Mouse", led by Muriel T. Davisson and Thomas H. Roderick, to start the "Mouse Genome Informatics" project Wikipedia, first published online in 1994 and currently maintained by The Jackson Laboratory staff.

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
License type: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC-BY) 

Permissions:


- Images accessible from the website are the copyrighted work of the attributed author or publisher unless otherwise noted.

- MGI database resources have permission to display images but not redistribute them.

- All images with distribution restrictions are labeled and users must abide by such restrictions

- The Mammalian Phenotype (MP) Ontology, Mouse Developmental Anatomy (EMAPA) Ontology, and Mouse Adult Anatomy Ontology (MA) are licensed under CC-BY 4.0.

- Attribution required when using data (cite "Mouse Genome Database (MGD), Mouse Genome Informatics, The Jackson Laboratory, Bar Harbor, Maine").

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
The Gene Ontology (GO) knowledgebase is the world's largest source of information on the functions of genes, providing structured controlled vocabularies (ontologies) describing three domains: molecular functions, biological processes, and cellular components, along with over 1,000,000 experimentally-supported annotations linking specific genes to ontology terms across multiple species.

In the proposal (additional info), the GO.obo dataset will map to the C5 (Ontology) collection for both Biological Process (BP) and Molecular Function (MF) sub-collections to connect genes to the functional nodes in our GO.obo hierarchy 

Aligns with the approved research topic of Bioscience.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation classified in Prohibited Use Screening in accordance with LC 2.7.

checks.name: D5+M affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
The GO Consortium is funded by the National Human Genome Research Institute (US National Institutes of Health), grant number HG012212, with co-funding by NIGMS

It is currently directed by Dr. Paul D. Thomas (Professor, University of Southern California/SIB Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics), with contributions from multiple model organism databases including The Jackson Laboratory, FlyBase, SGD, and UniProt.

All funding and governing entities are from non-D5 countries.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts
checks.notes: No user files provided.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: No risk identified in LC 2.7 check. Skipping inspection.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes:
Source: https://geneontology.org/

The GOC was established in 1998 when researchers studying the genome of three model organisms , Drosophila melanogaster (fruit fly), Mus musculus (mouse), and Saccharomyces cerevisiae (brewer's or baker's yeast). It began to work collaboratively on a common classification scheme for gene function; Michael Ashburner started the Gene Ontology project in 1998 with Suzanna Lewis, Judy Blake, David Botstein and Mike Cherry, with the foundational paper published in Nature Genetics in 2000, and is currently maintained by the international Gene Ontology Consortium led by Dr. Paul D. Thomas.

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
License type: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Unported License 

Permissions: 

- Any form of reuse of the content is permitted under CC BY 4.0.

- Users must provide identification/attribution of the Gene Ontology Consortium as the creator.

- Users must include a copyright notice and reference to the CC BY 4.0 license. 

- Users must provide a URI or hyperlink to the licensed material where practicable.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
STRING is a database of known and predicted protein-protein interactions covering 12,535 organisms, 59.3 million proteins, and over 20 billion interactions, integrating experimental data, computational prediction methods, text-mining of scientific literature, and curated pathway databases to provide both physical and functional protein associations with confidence scores.

The STRING database is listed in the additional information. It is described as providing "the Protein-Protein Interaction (PPI) network" which serves as "the connective tissue of our graph, allowing a 'Gene A' embedding to be influenced by its physical neighbor 'Protein B'"; it supports Pillar One (knowledge graph construction with PPI network edges), Pillar Two (training datasets with protein interaction features for embeddings), and Pillar Three (pathway discovery and target identification through protein network analysis).

Aligns with the approved research topic of Bioscience.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation classified in Prohibited Use Screening in accordance with LC 2.7.

checks.name: D5+M affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
STRING is developed and maintained by a consortium including SIB - Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics, CPR - Novo Nordisk Foundation Center Protein Research (University of Copenhagen), and EMBL - European Molecular Biology Laboratory. 

The principal investigators include Dr. Christian von Mering (Professor, University of Zurich/SIB; LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/christian-von-mering-122a67139/), Dr. Lars Juhl Jensen (Professor, Novo Nordisk Foundation Center for Protein Research, University of Copenhagen), and Dr. Peer Bork (formerly Director of EMBL Heidelberg).

All entities listed above are from non-D5 countries.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts
checks.notes: No user files provided.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: No risk identified in LC 2.7 check. Skipping inspection.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes:
Source: https://string-db.org/cgi/download?sessionId=bGQiABGDTiFT

STRING has been maintained continuously since the year 2000 ; the original publication was by Snel, B., Lehmann, G., Bork, P. and Huynen, M.A. (2000).

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
License type: Creative Commons BY 4.0

Permissions:

- STRING has recently changed its licensing model, at the request of the ELIXIR initiative, making all data freely available from the Download section

- When using the data, users must provide appropriate credit and inform users of any changes or additions made to the data

- API access should only be used for limited or occasional database access to avoid server overload.

- HTML page scraping is prohibited.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
ChEMBL is a manually curated database of bioactive molecules with drug-like properties, bringing together chemical, bioactivity and genomic data to aid the translation of genomic information into effective new drugs, containing 2-D structures, calculated properties (logP, molecular weight, Lipinski parameters), and abstracted bioactivities (binding constants Ki/Kd/IC50/EC50, pharmacology and ADMET data) extracted from over 86,000 journal articles and patents.

The dataset is listed in the additional information and is described as the proposal's bridge to chemistry that maps Proteins to small molecules with quantitative data enabling embeddings to have a potential drug dimension. It supports Pillar One (knowledge graph construction linking genes/proteins to small molecules), Pillar Two (training datasets with quantitative bioactivity features for drug-target embeddings), and Pillar Three (target discovery and drug repurposing through protein-compound interaction data).

Aligns with the approved research topic of Bioscience.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes:
Source: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chembl/

The database, originally known as StARlite, was developed by a biotechnology company called Inpharmatica Ltd. later acquired by Galapagos NV; the data was acquired for EMBL in 2008 with an award from The Wellcome Trust, resulting in the creation of the ChEMBL chemogenomics group at EMBL-EBI, led by John Overington. 

ChEMBL was launched as an open-access database for the first time in October 2009 . 

It is currently maintained by the Chemical Biology Services team at EMBL-EBI led by Dr. Andrew Leach and coordinated by Dr. Barbara Zdrazil.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
BioGRID is a biomedical interaction repository with data compiled through comprehensive curation efforts, searching 87,794 publications for 2,920,886 protein and genetic interactions, 31,540 chemical interactions and 1,128,339 post translational modifications from major model organism species. All BioGRID content is curated from primary experimental evidence in the biomedical literature, and includes both focused low-throughput studies and large high-throughput datasets. The database also includes the Open Repository of CRISPR Screens (ORCS) containing over 2,217 annotated CRISPR screens.

BioGRID is explicitly listed in the additional information. The PPI truth-set for evaluation: the training graph's edges (e.g. from STRING) will be benchmarked against BioGRID's experimentally-validated edges. BioGRID's focus on low-throughput, highly-reliable interactions makes it a gold standard." This supports Pillar One (knowledge graph validation and quality assurance), Pillar Two (benchmark datasets for evaluating embedding quality against experimentally-validated interactions), and Pillar Three (target discovery validation through high-confidence interaction networks).

Aligned with the approved research topic of Bioscience.

checks.name: D5+M affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
BioGRID is a curated biological database created in 2003 by Mike Tyers, Bobby-Joe Breitkreutz, and Chris Stark at the Lunenfeld-Tanenbaum Research Institute at Mount Sinai Hospital. 

The BioGRID is hosted in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and Dallas, Texas, United States and is partnered with the Saccharomyces Genome Database, FlyBase, WormBase.

Current principal investigators include Dr. Mike Tyers (Institut de Recherche en Immunologie et en Cancérologie, Université de Montréal) and Dr. Kara Dolinski (Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics, Princeton University). Funding comes from NIH Office of Research Infrastructure Programs, Canadian Institutes of Health Research, and Genome Canada.

All concerned entities are from non-D5 countries.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes: The precursor to BioGRID was originally conceived as a laboratory information management system (LIMS) for HTP interaction data. The first public release of BioGRID (version 1.0; July 2002; then termed GRID) housed HTP two-hybrid and mass spectrometric protein interaction data generated from the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.  BioGRID was developed initially as a project at the Lunenfeld-Tanenbaum Research Institute at Mount Sinai Hospital but has since expanded to include teams at the Institut de Recherche en Immunologie et en Cancérologie at the Université de Montréal and the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics at Princeton University. The original foundational publication is: Breitkreutz BJ, Stark C, Tyers M. "The GRID: the General Repository for Interaction Datasets." Genome Biol. 2003;4(3):R23.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
Reactome is a free, open-source, curated and peer-reviewed pathway database providing intuitive bioinformatics tools for the visualization, interpretation and analysis of pathway knowledge.

The dataset is listed in the additional information and is described as providing "reaction-level pathway detail" that maps to "C2:CP → gives us the well-defined pathways in GSEA's 'Canonical Pathways' subset" and enables "connecting genes/proteins into biological processes and disease pathways." This supports Pillar One (knowledge graph construction with mechanistic pathway information), Pillar Two (training datasets with reaction-level features and pathway hierarchies for embeddings), and Pillar Three (target discovery through pathway enrichment analysis and disease pathway annotations).

Aligns with the approved research topic of Bioscience.

Reactome is a collaboration between groups at the Ontario Institute for Cancer Research, Oregon Health & Science University, New York University Langone Medical Center, and The EMBL - European Bioinformatics Institute.

Founded in 2003, the Reactome project is led by Lincoln Stein of OICR, Peter D'Eustachio of NYU Langone Health, Henning Hermjakob of EMBL-EBI, and Guanming Wu of OHSU. Reactome
Principal Investigators:

Dr. Lincoln Stein (Acting Scientific Director, Ontario Institute for Cancer Research; LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/lincoln-stein-74532a16b/)

Founded in 2003 Reactome was originally developed at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory as described in the foundational publication: Joshi-Tope G, et al. "The Genome Knowledgebase: A Resource for Biologists and Bioinformaticists." Cold Spring Harb Symp Quant Biol. 2003;68:237-43. Prior to joining OICR in 2006, Dr. Stein played an integral role in many large-scale data initiatives at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory including leading the creation and development of Reactome. The database has been continuously updated with quarterly releases, now at Version 95.
